reviewTitle: Decent cable but can’t sustain true 4K HDR at 144hz
reviewDescription: I used this between PC and TV. TV is a TCL QM8, which has game mode, variable refresh, local dimming, HDR, and atmos. This cable couldn’t hold up to the task. Every few minutes, the screen would “reconnect”. After trying a different cable, I found this to be the culprit. This thing doesn’t actually seem capable of the 48gbps advertised.

reviewTitle: 30ft cable - getting black/blank screen every few minutes when running at 144Hz
reviewDescription: Unfortunately as soon as I put this cable in I'm getting occasional blank/black screens for 1-2 seconds (about every 3-5 minutes) with this 30ft cable when running 144Hz.  Using a shorter cable (10ft) does not shows this behavior, however I need to move the display further away so I think I need to find a fiber HDMI 2.1 8K cable.  Thanks

reviewTitle: 4K @ 120Hz HDR works some of the time...
reviewDescription: I've been using a 4K TV as a gaming monitor for my PC since 2016. I was using a QLED 55" screen and pretty much any HDMI cable I used worked to output 4K @ 60Hz and HDR + 10-bit color. I recently replaced that QLED with an OLED which can do 4K @ 120Hz and HDR + 10-bit color. Any old HDMI cable will no longer do.So here we are, The Highwings 8K cable, rated at 48Gbps. Does it work to support 120Hz and HDR? Sure it does, with caveats. Read on.After attaching this cable to my new LG G2 OLED TV and my RTX 3090 GPU, I had nothing but problems. Everything will work for a while but after some time, eventually, the HDR will go on and off like the TV is losing the signal, or these weird artifacts will appear across the screen. It wasn't very pleasant if I'm being honest.After this, I proceeded to purchase multiple HDMI 2.1 cables (some even claimed certification) but after buying 5 different brands, and all of them having issues with 4K / 120 Hz with HDR, I finally decided to go to a brick-and-mortar store and buy a $50 HDMI 2.1 certified cable. Would you like to guess what happened next?EVERYTHING WORKS PERFECTLY.So, if you really need a high-quality HDMI cable, maybe you'll get lucky with one of these cheap cables from Amazon, or maybe you can save yourself all the aggravation and just buy a good, brand-name cable from your local audio/video store.I've never been one to spend a lot on cables, and Amazon is my go-to for fair-priced cable options but one thing I found with these cheap HDMI 2.1 cables from Amazon, is they typically work out of the box/bag but during long hours of use, they start to fall short. Maybe they really aren't truly 48Gbps cables. I couldn't say. I can say I had nothing but issues and when finally un-tightening my butt cheeks and spending $50 on a name-brand cable (probably made in China too but to a higher standard) everything just worked. I could have saved myself a lot of research and time./edit. I am going to repeat this very review for each of the HDMI cables I bought recently that were not up to snuff.

I bought the 1 foot and 1.5 foot cable lengths. They seem to be of a good build quality. However, be aware that these cables are very, very stiff and they come looped. This means that the cable is curled in one direction, and you hope that it's the direction you need it to curl in!Additionally, the length is a bit misleading. The measurement is from the tip of of each connector. The cable length itself ends up being about 8 inches for the 1 foot and 13" for the 1.5 foot.No issues with signal transmission so far, but I had to twist them 180° to connect two pieces of equipment. With the stiffness I do have some concern about it twisting the ports into which it's plugged. I am most likely going to return them for a different cable because of these issues.

The cable worked for a number of months and then after moving my computer to a new location the cable has stopped working after unplugging in and then plugging it back in once my computer was set back up.

reviewTitle: Does not work with Sonos Arc
reviewDescription: Does not work with Sonos Arc. It keeps falling out and disconnecting.

reviewTitle: Low quality shipping. Doesn't work well
reviewDescription: It shipped in it's thin cardboard box which was open upon delivery. The cable was coming out a bit. The cable seems high quality, but it's very stiff and heavy. When playing games at 4k 120hz, it glitches ever 5 minutes or so. Just turns black for a few seconds, and then goes back to normal. Other cables work fine, so it's not my devices. I'd recommend anyone needing 25ft just get a fiber optic cable, and save yourself the headache.
De los dos que compré uno salió malo no funciona
Mediocre unlit for the price

reviewTitle: Didn't really improve the quality of the picture
reviewDescription: 4k tv

reviewTitle: Wrong length and Does not work with 4k 120hz
reviewDescription: As title says, this does not work when using it connect my rtx 3080  gaming PC to any of the  HDMI 2.1 (4k 120hz /144hz)  ports on my tcl qm8. No issues when  connected to 4k 60hz port. Also the 15ft I ordered is definitely shorter than 15 ft. More like 12 ft this is a bummer because I bought this so that I don't have to keep my PC near my TV stand.  And unfortunately I didn't test it immediately since I was doing some other remodeling work in the room. Now I am past the return window!Update.  Just the say that it was indeed the right length (15ft) that was sent. However the complaint about the 4k 120hz signal still holds. I even reversed directions and they didn't help much. No signal or just flickering.

I was using this for a gaming setup. To get my computer farther away because the heat from the exhaust is unbearable. Unfortunately this does not support 120 hz like it says. At 120 hz i have to turn off free sync, motion blur reduction and hdr just to get a picture. Even then the picture is very pixelated and blacks out about every 30 seconds. The only solid picture i saw was at 60 hz. Switched to a rocket bunny cord and my issue was solved immediately.

Short version:junk - don't buy - poor video even at lower than rated bandwidthLonger version:My setup is pretty simplePanasonic UB820 player >> HDFury Vertex2 >> Epson 5050UBThe Panasonic is only used for playing blurays and UHD blurays, no streaming. I decided to do some cabling upgrades in my system and was going to use this "8k" cable to replace the old "4k" cable between the Panasonic player and the HDFury (3.3ft cable). After installing the new 8k Highwings cable I was seeing video dropouts and sync issues for up to 5 minutes after any resolution or frame-rate change, such as going between menus and content. Also seeing a lot of sparkles in the picture, and I mean this was sparkling more than the chrome on my neighbors motorcycle. This was happening at 4k-24p 422-12bit (DV/HDR). I had ordered three of these cables, so I tried a second 8k cable, did the exact same thing. I put the 4 year old "4k" cable back in (a rocketfish, BTW) and all the problems went away. Tried a second time with the two 8k cables, and still no bueno.If they have problems at 4k24 I can't imagine they are working any better at 4k120 or 8k60.

This cable went bad quickly. I have it connected between my ps5 and capture card and thought the capture card went out, but nope. Changed this cord out to a different brand and style and immediately worked. In fact, I have had 3 hdmi cords in this style just go bad. Most recently was a 10ft 8k cord I take for traveling, bought a ge cord from Walmart and it worked immediately.

reviewTitle: Expensive, useless junk.  Don't do it.
reviewDescription: I bought this cable to connect my iPad to a recent model Sony flat screen TV using an Apple Lightning to HDMI connector.  WIthin a few weeks, the sound would contimue but the picture went black from time to time, more and more frequently. I only yesterday thought to try a different HDMI cable and confirmed that this one is useless. And of course only 3 days after the return window closed. Claimed to have a lifetime warranty but I retained no info from the manufaturer.

reviewTitle: Does not support 4k 120Hz with a Playstation 5
reviewDescription: I really wanted this to work so that I wouldn't have to keep bringing my Playstation 5 to different areas of my home, but the best I got was 4k 60p. I don't know if there is a limitation based on cable length but boy what a disappointment.

reviewTitle: Sound keeps dropping out with video and with some games at max resolution
reviewDescription: Whenever I play a game at 4k with the settings maxed out, the sound cuts out as well as severe stutter at times.Also, the sound cuts out with certain movies like UHD 4k movies.Seems like a bandwidth issue at the upper end.This is also with the refresh rate set to 120hz that there is a problem.

Ordered these because I needed longer HDMI cables. They do not work well. It seems at least once every ten minutes my sound cuts out for a brief second before returning. Additionally, I will occasionally lose picture for a second or two. It isn’t as frequent but I have also lost sound and picture enough that it seems to reset my whole system. Pretty bummed that things like this cannot just work the way they are supposed to…

This cable sat connected, but hardly touched in my entertainment center for 5 months before spontaneously ceasing to work. I’m not sure how a cable can suddenly self destruct like that, but I imagine it speaks to the lack of quality in its design. If you need a cable that works, I suggest looking elsewhere.

I used this item going from my receiver to the tv. It worked fine for about 3 weeks. Over the last week, I’ve been noticing issues with lines in the picture (tv program) but attributed it to the carrier having local problems. Then I started hearing a periodic tick coming from my speakers. After doing some troubleshooting, I saw that the issue was from the 3 hdmi cables I replaced. Any contact to them from a power cord would result in issues with sound and picture quality. I replaced the cables with my old ones and all the issues are gone. Unfortunately, I’m outside of my return window by 3 days now. Bear in mind, this was used in a home theater. There are always going to be cables close to each other. I would NOT recommend using these cables.

reviewTitle: I had issues with mine, replaced it and so far so good... RTX-4090 + LG C3
reviewDescription: I ended up trying this cable because it had really good feedback, I was using it from an RTX-4090 to an LG C3 OLED and in my dual display setup I noticed I'd have my main display (this one) cutting out sometimes and doing a weird blocky pattern which I thought was a Chromium issue based on countless reddit, forum, etc. posts so I just assumed that's all it was.It eventually started getting worse where my picture would cut out for a second just doing normal stuff like Photoshop or browsing and sound would go with it as well often times for a split second while my other monitor never even flickered (Display Port).I was worried by the frequency and strange artifact/checker pattern sometimes and was kind of scared my expensive and basically brand new GPU was problematic / defective but since I replaced this with a similarly priced Anker cable I haven't had an issue yet (knock on wood).I also saw noticeable stepping in gradients, I'm always doing creative work and dark gradients showed prominent stepping between tonal levels and that seemed odd for such a high end GPU and pretty damn good TV as well, my Sony Bravia I used from 2016-2024 never had a similar issue.I'm guessing that was the cable too... this might be a good cable most of the time, maybe I was just unlucky and got a bad one but yeah, my experience is a lot better since replacing it so far.

I intended to use this HDMI cable to do the simplest of vanilla tasks:  I  was going to use it to connect my HP Chromebook to a flat-screen monitor so I could use a bigger computer display.  It connects OK, and everything electronic seems to work, but the only image it will display on the external monitor is the desktop image from the computer without ever having any icons or writing on top of it.  I don't see how this is possible.  My only guess is that the complexity level that humans have allowed is too high.  Since this HDMI cable enables USB and other digital intercommunication between the devices, I can only guess that HP or LG (monitor manufacturer) screwed up their implementation of some standard which should allow the HDMI video to stream to the monitor screen by default.  I doesn't do that.  I can't make it do that.I guess my advice would have to be:  Don't buy this cable if you want to connect your computer to an external monitor.  Get an old-style dumb HDMI cable that can only stream video, and does not simultaneously enable digital communication, because this smart cable won't allow me to do the simplest most basic thing that HDMI was created  to do:  Stream video.

reviewTitle: It worked for a little while
reviewDescription: It was good and worked for a little while on my TV and such, I stopped using it for a good few months though, then started using it for my PC and it was fine for a month or so.Unfortunately it started having issues at the connection and the screen flickers black occasionally and I have to wiggle it. Not fun when you're in the middle of something.The cord is thick and long, it looks like it's sturdy and for the price that's great- if only the connection parts weren't screwy...

reviewTitle: Cheap Connections & Only 30 Days to Return
reviewDescription: Every once in a while my tv would suddenly go black for moment and it took me a while to finally start investigating. I finally found it was the connectors on this cord. The connection is so poor that barely touching the cord would make my tv lose signal. I had assumed I would still be under warranty because most sellers in America give 1 year for electronics, but no. Not this company. 30 days is all you get. Unless you don’t mind really rolling the dice, I suggest you buy a better product, especially one with at least a year warranty.

reviewTitle: Very stiff cable. Could hardly keep it plugged in.
reviewDescription: I purchased this 15 ft HDMI cable to run a TV for homeschooling my grandsons. It worked at first but the cable is so thick and stiff that it would disconnect from the computer with any movement at all. Unusable. Perhaps I can return it.

I had this cable for 8 months and while the build quality is great, I finally realized the HDMI ARC problem I've been having is because of this cable.  I this cable connected from my TV to my avr.  I have another android box connected to my TV HDMI port.  My TV setup box is connected to my avr.  When I'm watching TV and decide to switch to my android box, I always never get any sound initially.  I've always had to turn off the AVR and turn it back on for the Android box to have sound.  I researched this and I had thought it is because my avr is at 12 years is too old. Finally I bought another cable to test this.  Right away the problem went away.  I am able to switch between my TV set top box and my android box without having no sound.  So it was this cable all along that has problems with ARC.  Too bad I can't return it now but at least I figured it my problem of 8 months!

This HDMI has a horrible connection. It keeps disconnecting and causing the screen to go black and part of the picture gets staticy, also there ends up being blue lines everywhere. I know it's not my PlayStation 5 because when I hook it up to my other TV with a different cord it doesn't do this. Also, when I hook-up PC to the main monitor with a different cord it doesn't do it.

I tried a few cables and none of them work with Apple TV4k to pass Dolby Vision content @4k 60Hz. Many of the cables I tried only pass Dolby Vision @4k 30Hz signal with shorter cable length and some don't work with Apple TV4k even with lower refresh rate and shorter HDMI cables. I bought two different lengths of the Highwings 8K HDMI cables (15 feet and 20 feet) and both pass Dolby Vision with 4k@ 60Hz with 422 12-bit color and 4k@ 60Hz with 444 color for HDR. I can FINALLY send custom EDID with 4k60 422 12-bit color from my HDFury Vertex2 to my JVC projector. Awesome!UPDATE: I am revising my review and reducing my rating to two stars as the 20 feet cable failed after a short period of use. The cable frequently drops a 4k @60hz Dolby Vision signal from Apple TV. I get no image but a snowy picture when it does that. I have to unplug and reconnect the cable to make it work but after 10 minutes or so later, the drops the signal again. The 15-foot cable form the same brand still works with Dolby vision SO FAR, but I doubt the longevity of these cable. The last cable I had from Monoprice and Blue Jeans still works after several years of ownership. I will be returning this cable and look for a certified version HDMI 48 Gbps cable.

I followed directions from a YouTube tutorial on how to connect my smart TV to my old school receiver with 4 speakers a subwoofer using an HDMI cable. It worked great for one week; now there’s feedback when turning on the TV also volume is turned up to 40+ on both for medium sound quality. Has anyone else have issues? If so PLZZZ share how to resolve and ThnkU !!!

reviewDescription: It was a great cable. Worked for 7 weeks. Then it just stopped working. Used another hdmi and the devices that weren’t connecting worked again, so it’s definitely the cable. I’d like to return it, but the return time frame is passed, of course…. Wouldn’t recommend.

Having tried this HDMI cable with a regular Blu-Ray player and then a 4K Blu-Ray player hooked up to an HD TV, picture and audio quality were great. Although I haven't tried it hooked up to a 4K TV, I see no reason why its performance wouldn't be equally acceptable, since the cable is designed for up to 8K performance. And the fact that this cable is more than six feet (two meters) long means it is great for connecting devices that cannot always be conveniently co-located.I have no complaints about this product.

I was experiencing intermittent video loss with my home theatre setup. After I verified my display settings I used this to connect my lg c4 to my denon x3800h and then to my xbox. It solved my issues. I'm running full 4k 120hz without an issue now.

reviewTitle: Failed after a few months, cannot reach customer service
reviewDescription: It was working fine for a few months, but then suddenly it started having flashing screen artifacts, or turning to black repeatedly, making it completely useless. Emailed the address found on the back of the box claiming a "lifetime warranty" several times, but never got any response. The warranty is completely useless, so only buy if you don't mind gambling on whether the cable you get will still work after a few months.

reviewTitle: DOES NOT SUPPORT LISTED REFRESH RATES
reviewDescription: This cable lies about its tech specs. It only supports 60Hz at 2K. Using the cables that came with my graphics card, my monitor can do 120Hz. I bought this after that original HDMI cable was damaged, and this can only do 60Hz at 2K. Don't support this scam.
2nd day of having it stopped supporting 4k from my xbox to TV

reviewTitle: Worked well for a month, then junk. Best to avoid this and buy a better, albeit pricier cable.
reviewDescription: I bought this to connect my pc to my 4k TV across the room and it worked great the first month or so. Running at full 120hz and 4k resolution - games were looking pretty and runnin smooth. I mounted the cable to baseboards around the room to keep it out of the way, so it wasn't being wiggled around or stepped on or anything. Once mounted it didn't move.Today it started dropping signal every 40-60 seconds for about 5-15 seconds, displaying a black screen. I checked my settings (which hadn't changed since setup), connection points at each in, drivers, etc... All were fine, no random changes I wasn't aware of. So, I swapped the cable out with another high speed HDMI cable and played with that for a few hours without a single issue. Sucks because my other cable is too short to tuck out of the way and I'm out of the refund window for this junk cable.Although, it is a really hefty braided cable, so maybe I can use it to secure loads in the bed of my truck. Or as an escape rope or somethingI regret not spending the extra 20-30 bucks to get a real brand

Even after I switched backed to the factory hdmi cable, crackle kept happening but eventually went away.Extremely disappointed in this cable. Everything I read said it was good, it is not!! Someone else actually tested the speed and it’s not a 2.1. Wish I could return.
Was wrong size plus wouldn’t fit

It’s a nice looking cable, feels solid, nice braid.Sadly, like so many other uncertified cables over 15’, it does not perform as advertised.Random black screens and flickering inundate the entire screen with irritating and unusable frequency.Had to return.

I replaced this cable with a certified and tested one recommended by HDTV calibrator and suddenly all my problems went away. It cost 3x this one but was worth it. With this cable I would lose HDR often and rarely it would just go blank. I would have to turn everything off and on again to get it back. New cable proves it was this cable that was the issue.

Turning things on and off would mostly solved it so all devices stayed on 4K but then audio would cut out every few seconds.I tried a different 30 ft cable and all works now. This one is going back.

We got a new TV recently, a lower end 43 inch Samsung 4k with hdcp 2.2 compatibility on all ports.  All ports are hdmi 2.0. We have several other 4k TVs which we had noticed were performing worse over the last months--lots of buffering, etc, and sometimes not even being able to connect at all to 4k content.  With this new TV, we immediately started getting hdcp errors using the same 4k hdmi cables we were using with the other TVs.  These errors were the clue that caused us to reassess the cables for all the TVs. I ordered 2 of these and installed one on the new TV and one on an older 4K TV (also hdcp 2.2 compatibility and hdmi 2.0 on all hdmi ports) that had been slowing down and reducing 4k content to 1080p content for months. I had always heard that the 4k@60 cables would do the job, and they did for years, but things change.  These new 8k cables fixed the hdcp problems we were having, and both TVs are streaming 4k smoothly with no problem now on Prime Video, Netflix, Paramount Plus, etc.  I'm ordering more!

So, looks like the shielding is not quite good enough for 48Gbps, or something.

reviewTitle: 15ft is not a certified HDMI 2.1 cable
reviewDescription: The Ultra High Speed HDMI Certification Program is a mandatory certification program for all Ultra High Speed HDMI Cables. The 15ft cable does not carry this certification.

SOLID QUALITY

reviewTitle: Weird artifacting / interference issues with LG C2 and multiple inputs
reviewDescription: I bought 3 of these and they all experience the same weird issue so buyer beware if your situation is similar:I have an LG C2 oled TV which is usually connected to both my PC and a macbook. When I started using these cables my pc output would start flickering colors and artifacts and I thought my gpu was dying. I discovered the issue was that whenever I had multiple inputs connected with these cables I'd get the same result. It seems okay if I use this cable from the macbook (pushing 4k 60hz) and an older hdmi 2.1 cable coming from my pc (4k 120hz) but if I used this cable from my PC to the c2 and even had another input simply touching the metal shroud of a different hdmi port it would immediately begin flickering and artifacting. No clue what the technical issue is here but it was super annoying. The issue probably isn't with the TV, because like I said, a different brand hdmi cable pushes the pixels out fine regardless of what else is connected.Figured this review might help if someone comes here trying to diagnose a specific technical issue. These might just not be up to pushing 4k / 120hz reliably.

reviewTitle: I gave a three as the HDMI Cable is a five.  However, the adapter is a one.
reviewDescription: The HDMI cable connect a DVD player to my TV.  Just what I needed, works fine.  The adapter does not work at all.  I am trying to get an old CD burner to work with a new IMac.  This connects everything, but nothing works.

On the positive side, this cable appears to do what is claimed. I can't confirm that it supports an 8K signal, but it does support an HDR 4K signal at 120fps, connecting an Apple TV 4K (2021 version) to an LG C1 OLED TV. It also appears to be eARC properly.So why do I only give it three stars?There are two nasty flaws.First is that it has a built-in velcro thingie that I expect someone thought was a great idea for helping you wind up the cable. Maybe so, but my experience was that this damn velcro kept catching on table cloths, curtains, and anything else near to the cable as I was trying to arrange it.Second is the cable is surprisingly stiff. I expected something like an HDMI 1.2 cable, or ethernet; very flexible  and easy to bend. Instead this is more like coax, with a very wide bending radius. Enough of a problem that where I'd previously used a 3' cable as the perfect length, doing the job and easy to hide, I now had to get a 6' cable and try to wrap the excess around the back of the TV while never bending it too much. Maybe the specs demand that all 8K HDMI cables have to be this stiff, so it's not this manufacturer's fault, I don't know. All I can say is be prepared for something a lot stiffer than you expected, both in terms of requiring something longer than you expected, and in terms of having to find a way to hide the excess cable that's bulges out at turns and bends.
Had problems connecting my equipments.  Soundbar wouldn't connect via ARC

What I did not like was the name label is an applied stick on label, I purchased 4 of these and they all fit loose (almost too small) in HDMI sockets of 3 different devices, although they did work OK, I believe the stickon label will eventually fall off, No instructions and no direction to and from source to device. Fix these and it would be a BEST BUY for the money

reviewTitle: Don't buy longer than 12ft for HDMI 2.1 passive
reviewDescription: I bought this cable without thinking. I was needing a 30ft HDMI 2.1 cable so I could run the cable from one corner of my room to the other. However, I never thought to look up what the HDMI 2.1 specifications were graded for as a passive (Non-Powered, Non-Optical) cable. Turns out, HDMI 2.1 is only graded for 10ft, with a theoretical limit of 15ft. Anything more and you will get signal degradation. I found this out the hard way when, shortly after installing it, I noticed that every so often, my monitor would go solid black for about 1-2 seconds then come back on and would do this about 1-3 times every hour. I'm sure the fault isn't with any defects in the cable, but instead with the fact that it's too long a cable to carry that type of signal for that amount of distance. Anyhow, If you need more than 12-15ft for an HDMI 2.1 cable, get a USB powered one or an Optical variant so it will be able to carry the signal the entire distance. Anyhow, that's my PSA.

reviewTitle: Decent cable, but not perfect by any means
reviewDescription: After buying another cable on Amazon that supposedly supported 4 @120 hrz ( but didn't work at all ) it's refreshing to see my tv work at that refresh rate with this cable. Just like people said on the top reviews this seems to fully support the refresh rate at the 4k resolution. Though, there is a catch that I ha e not seen mentioned. For whatever reason my cable has no audio pass through whatsoever, if you where hoping to use your surround sound or a good pair of TV headphones there seems to be no working audio pass through. This is a pretty big flaw, but since I'm using my computer headset and have no other issues with the cable I think it is fair to give it 3 stars. So if you are planning on using this for your PC set up, just know that that the audio pass though may not work and you will have to use your desktop headset.

Got this product thinking it would be better than the factory supplied ps5 hdmi cable, this was not the case. Only thing I cared about was getting a steadier frame rate at 120hz, but I saw greater frame drop than the factory ps5 cable. The high wing dropped as low as 40fps while I was gaming while the ps5 cable had never dropped below 80. If you’re just looking for a cheap replacement because yours broke then by all means get this, if you’re looking for an upgrade then learn from my mistake and don’t buy this product.
The performance of this device is great however the cable is too stiff and rough to move around

Picture quality is great. Value for the money is great.The only low point I have with this product is that the connectors do not fit snuggly / securely into any HDMI port I have tried them on. This can be troublesome if the cables or equipment get moved for any reason (moving/extendable mounts are a great example), as the cables come lose very easily.If you are looking for low cost and don't need to worry about movement, these will do the job... If you need the connections to be more secure I would advise looking for a different cable.

Main problem: It’s a good/cheap cable. The braiding, however is so stiff that it starts wrenching at the ports if you’re trying to do cable management (wall mounting on an extending/articulating wall mount where wires must be carefully considered to prevent tensing/pinching across full motion).Minor annoyance: the stiffness of the cable combined with a BARELY loose fit in the eARC port of my Sonos Arc has been sporadically causing a brief connection  issue in the HDCP “handshake” across source—>tv—>soundbar that kills the signal while it reconnects. I THINK I’ve fixed it with a single layer of form fit electrical tape wrapped around the border of the hdmi to promote a tighter fit. Either way it doesn’t loose connection by simply touching the cable now which is a huge plus.
The cable would not maintain a stable 8K 60Hz signal (signal loss every 4-5 minutes). Replaced by the amazon brand (better price) and it has worked without issue.

Using the cable as an eARC between an 85” Sony Bravia TV and a Onkyo TX-RZ50 receiver. What a difference! The lag is not as bad as when I was using a standard hdmi cable same length. Increasing/decreasing the volume is quicker than before. The standard hdmi not only caused a lag but would also not respond at times when changing the volume. Streaming has also improved when using the eARC connection. No pausing is occurring like before. If you’re wondering, I don’t go cheap on my internet speed to cause pausing, it was the standard cable. Also, I don’t see a noticeable change of video/audio. Lastly, it’s not instantaneous response otherwise I would rate it a 5 star. However, the price is better than paying $100-200 for the hi-fi name brand cables that I researched. Hope this review helps you!

Just be aware that they are made outside the US and thus are made in metric lengths, so the listed lengths in feet are only approximations.

reviewTitle: Works fine but something is weird
reviewDescription: In first place, i give only 4 stars just as a precaution, please, read the last paragraph.Effectively this is a certified "Ultra High Speed HDMI Cable", i've verified with the "HDMI Cable" app, that's a good start.In my case i've used to connect my RTX3080 12GB to a Samsung 50" Neo QLED 4K QN90A (QN50QN90AAK),with previows cables from other weird brands i was suffering of random flickering, sometimes just a couple in 1 hour; with this cable as far as i've tested the flicker is gone, even using the most demanding resolution that my rig can achieve, 3840x2160 @120Hz 10bit YCbCr444; no artifacts, no sound issues, variable refresh rate works fine too, overall it works as expected, i'm satisfied in this regard  wtihout doubts.HOWEVER, i must be clear, there is something weird here that is good that you know, at least in my case, if i use the Samsung  built in function to test the hdmi cable the test fails and it recommends to replace the cable, to be honest i don't know if that test is reliable, at least in my real life test this is the 1st cable that works properly without any issues, maybe at 144Hz there can be issues, i have no way to test at that refresh rate so i don't know.

I do wonder how well it will work with the looseness of the plug though (will it loosen and fall out over time?) I might put a piece of tape to hold it in the port more securely.

The cable is very robust and excellent quality build. The one issue I encountered is that it is inflexible. In my application it is connecting the EARC  output of a Samsung QLED 85 to a Sonos ARC sound bar. Due to the limited space at the input of the sound bar the HDMI connector has a tendency to back out of the female receptor. Tried to make a 45 degree bend in the cable however due to its structural rigidity it was impossible to make a tight enough radius. If the cable had a 45 degree connector it would have been beneficial. For straight in application this is a great cable.
